data.title: Loomis AB (publ) reports Q4 results
data.description:
• Loomis AB (publ) press release (OTCPK:LOIMF): Q4 Revenue for the fourth quarter was SEK 7,926 million, up 6.9% Y/Y.
  • Earnings per share before dilution for the quarter were SEK 5.89.
  • Board of Directors proposes a dividend, for 2024, of SEK 14.00 per share

data.title: FMC downgraded at Bank of America; shares plunge on weak outlook
data.description:
FMC (NYSE:FMC) on Wednesday was downgraded to Underperform from a previous investment rating of Neutral by analysts at Bank of America. They said the maker of insecticides and other farming chemicals faces a weak outlook, as disclosed on Tuesday in the company’s quarterly earnings report.

Shares of FMC (NYSE:FMC) plunged 25% in extended trading after disclosing fourth-quarter results.

“Yesterday’s earnings release highlighted additional broader and company-specific challenges which in our view raise FMC’s risk profile substantially,” Steve Byrne, analyst at BofA, said in a note to clients.

The bank cut its price target for FMC (FMC) to $48 a share from $61 a share, based on an estimated enterprise value that’s 9.5 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for 2025.

Analysts at RBC Capital Markets also downgraded their rating on FMC (FMC).

data.title: Canada records trade surplus in Dec; exports climbed 10-month high, imports hit fresh record high
data.description:
• Canada posted a trade surplus of C$0.7 billion in December 2024, swinging from the upwardly revised deficit of C$1 billion in the previous month, and loosely in line with market expectations of a C$0.75 billion surplus.
  • Canadian exports climbed 4.9% to a 10-month high of CAD 69.5 billion in December 2024, following an upwardly revised CAD 66.2 billion in November and marking the highest level since May 2022.
  • Imports to Canada rose by 2.3% over a month to CAD 68.8 billion in December 2024, a fresh record high, after an upwardly revised 2.8% advance in the prior month.

  • ETFs: (EWC), (FLCA).

    Currency: (USD:CAD) (USD:CAD)

data.title: Intercontinental Exchange reports 21% rise in January average daily volume
data.description:
• Intercontinental Exchange (NYSE:ICE) announced on Wednesday that its January 2025 average daily volume rose 21% from last year.
  • Energy ADV increased 26% year-over-year. Oil ADV increased by 36%, Natural Gas ADV by 13%, and Environmentals ADV by 28%.
  • Sugar ADV was up 29% on a yearly basis, while the Cotton open interest increased by 14%.
  • Financials ADV grew 19% from last year, and NYSE Cash Equities ADV and NYSE Equity Options ADV by 17%.

data.title: Silicon Laboratories gets upgrade at Benchmark on industry recovery, market share gains
data.description:
Benchmark Equity upgraded Silicon Laboratories' (NASDAQ:SLAB) stock to Buy from Hold with a $166 price target, citing solid 2025 industry recovery and market share gains.

Shares of Silicon were up about 1% premarket on Wednesday.

Analyst Cody Acree said that as Silicon Labs finally worked through the bulk of excess industry and customer inventory levels, the company posted an in-line December quarter (fourth quarter) performance on its top and bottom-lines, with flat sales sequentially which matched its original fourth-quarter guidance.

The analyst noted that though the company's sequentially flat sales paused its prior three-quarters of growth since its business bottomed in the fourth quarter of last year, Silicon provided its first return to annual growth in eight quarters, with its last annual growth posted in the first quarter of 2023

On a flat sequential gross margin, and a $1.2M sequential decline in operating expenses, Silicon's fourth-quarter non-GAAP loss per share was $0.11, which matched the company’soriginal forecast and its Street consensus estimate, Acree noted.

Acree said they believe Silicon has managed well through a difficult industry correction and the company appears to finally be coming out the other side of the macro pressure.

The analyst added that the company's forward Price to Earnings, or P/E, valuation is still high to a point of discomfort but they think its fundamentals are turning a corner and that its estimates should have a positive bias from this point forward through the breadth of the next industry up-cycle, which they expect to last through 2026.

data.title: Toyota boosts EV and battery production in China and U.S. as Q3 profit soars
data.description:
Toyota Motor (NYSE:TM) is ramping up its electric vehicle (EV) and battery production efforts with new initiatives in both China and the U.S., following a surge in its third quarter profit.

The company has partnered with the Shanghai government to build a new facility in Jinshan district, southwest of Shanghai, where it will produce Lexus EVs starting in 2027. With an initial production capacity of 100,000 vehicles annually, the project is expected to generate around 1,000 new jobs.

In addition, Toyota has announced plans to begin manufacturing batteries for EVs, hybrids, and plug-ins at a $14 billion facility in North Carolina. The plant, set to begin shipping batteries for North American models in April, will create approximately 5,000 jobs.

These moves come as Toyota reported a significant 61% jump in its fiscal third-quarter profit, which rose to 2.19 trillion yen ($14B) from the previous year.

This growth was driven by 12.4 trillion yen ($81B) in sales, up 3% from the same period last year. The company attributed the increase to recovering sales following a production halt earlier this fiscal year due to a certification issue in Japan.

Toyota also revised its full-year profit forecast, now expecting 4.5 trillion yen ($29B) in profit through March 2025, up from its previous projection of 3.6 trillion yen ($24B). However, the revised forecast still falls short of the 4.9 trillion yen ($32B) profit achieved in the previous fiscal year.

Toyota credited favorable foreign exchange rates and cost reduction efforts for the positive revision.

Source: Press release

data.title: Yamaha reports 9M results
data.description:
• Yamaha press release (OTCPK:YAMCF): 9M revenue increased by ¥8.9 billion (+2.6%) year-on-year to ¥350.7 billion.
  • Core operating profit increased by ¥4.1 billion (+14.9%) year on year to ¥31.9 billion, mainly due to the impact of the yen depreciation.
  • For the fiscal year ending March 31, 2025, the Company maintains its full-year revenue forecast of ¥460.0 billion.
  • However, core operating profit has been revised downward from ¥37.0 billion (+9.9% year on year) to ¥33.0 billion (-1.9% year on year).
  • Profit for the period attributable to the owners of the parent has been revised downward from ¥18.0 billion (-39.3% year on year) to ¥13.5 billion (-54.5% year on year).

data.title: KKR-backed Cotiviti close to deal to buy Edifecs for $3B - FT
data.description:
KKR-backed healthcare data firm Cotiviti is nearing a deal to acquire smaller rival Edifecs for more than $3 billion after deciding against a higher bid from UnitedHealth (NYSE:UNH).

UnitedHealth (NYSE:UNH) offered $3.5 billion for Edifecs, though it was likely rejected in favor of the lower bid from Cotiviti on the likelihood that a UNH deal may be challenged by antitrust regulators, according to a Financial Times report on Wednesday, which cited people familiar with the matter. Cotiviti was also willing to move quicker than UNH to get a deal done.

Talks are ongoing, though a deal is near being finalized, according to the report.

Edifecs and KKR declined to comment to the FT. UnitedHealth didn't return requests for comment.

Edifecs decision to go with the lower offer comes after the Dept. of Justice sued to block UnitedHealth's planned $3.3 billion purchase of home health and hospice provider Amedisys (AMED) in November.

data.title: American Assets Trust raises dividend by 1.5% to $0.340
data.description:
• American Assets Trust (NYSE:AAT) declares $0.340/share quarterly dividend, 1.5% increase from prior dividend of $0.335.
  • Forward yield 5.66%
  • Payable March 20; for shareholders of record March 6; ex-div March 6.
  • See AAT Dividend Scorecard, Yield Chart, & Dividend Growth.

data.title: USPS reverses track and says it will accept international inbound packages from China and Hong Kong
data.description:
The United States Postal Service announced on Wednesday that it continue accepting all international inbound mail and packages from China and Hong Kong Posts. The USPS said it is working closely with the Customs and Border Protection agency to implement an efficient collection mechanism for the new China tariffs to ensure the least disruption to package delivery.

The announcement arrived just hours after the USPS had suspended service for the regions. The USPS decision does not impact the additional 10% tariff on Chinese goods or the closing of the "de minimis" trading loophole.

The de minimis trade exemption is a provision in U.S. trade law that allows packages valued under $800 to enter the U.S. duty-free and with minimal customs inspection. The exemption, which has been in place since the 1930s, has attracted significant attention lately due to its widespread use by e-commerce companies, particularly those based in China.
